PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: William George Vickers
Address: Fort Qu'Appelle
Birthplace: Lindsay, Victoria County, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1889
Where did you set up housekeeping? Fort Qu'Appelle
Where had you been living before that? Fort Qu'Appelle
For how many people did you prepare meals? 2
How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
sugar, tea, salt, flour, evaporated fruit, raisins, canned prune, fresh meat, bacon, canned beef, corn, beef, condensed milk

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Agilvers
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? yes How far away? 2 weeks What year? 1889
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 60¢
What other grain products did you use? rice
Cornmeal? no Whole Wheat? yes Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? no
How did you grind it?
1889. Vicars, William George
Fort Qu'Appelle.
